title: US Presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders has heart attack
text:
Democratic presidential candidate, Bernie Sanders, has been released from hospital (Picture: AP)

Bernie Sanders, one of the Democratic presidential candidates, has suffered a heart attack.

The 78-year-old was campaigning when he experienced chest discomfort and was taken to hospital.

Medics there confirmed he had a heart attack, his campaign team has said.

The senator had surgery where doctors in Las Vegas inserted two stents to open up a blocked artery in his heart.

The attack happened on Tuesday but was confirmed after he was released from hospital yesterday.

Doctors said the rest of his stay was ‘uneventful’ and his progress has been good.

Mr Sanders said he planned to get back to campaigning for the 2020 race soon.

The 78-year-old said he plans to be back on the campaign trail soon (Picture: AFP)

His team released a statement where the politician thanked the doctors, nurses and hospital staff.

He said: ‘After two and a half days in the hospital, I feel great, and after taking a short time off, I look forward to getting back to work.’

Mr Sanders is expected to return to his home state of Vermont before returning to the campaign trail.

This marks the second time in two months that health problems forced Mr Sanders to cancel campaign events.

In September, he backed out of some appearances in South Carolina because he lost his voice.

His campaign said at the time that Mr Sanders felt fine.

Bernie Sanders is hoping to take over from Donald Trump, aged 73 (Picture: AP)

As the oldest candidate in the Democratic 2020 field at 78, Mr Sanders has sometimes jokingly referenced his age on the campaign trail.

He is one of three septuagenarians who are leading the crowded race and have sparked questions within the party about whether Democrats need to coalesce around a younger leader.

Current president Donald Trump is 73.

A blocked artery can cause a heart attack, which just means that an area of the heart is suffering and in danger of damage because it is not getting enough blood or oxygen.

An artery-opening procedure like the one Mr Sanders had, and placing stents, which are tiny scaffolds to keep the artery open, restores blood flow and helps prevent future problems.

One of Mr Sanders’ arteries was blocked but the others were normal, doctors said.
